question: 3 (d)
sols_html:
We know from the previous part of the question that

\[\begin{aligned} f'(x) = \frac{\cos x - \sin x}{e^x}\end{aligned}\]

We take the derivative of \(\displaystyle f'(x)\) to find:

\[\begin{aligned} f''(x) &= \frac{(-\sin x - \cos x)e^x - (e^x)(\cos x - \sin x)}{(e^x)^2} &= \frac{e^x (-\sin x - \cos x - \cos x + \sin x)}{(e^x)^2} &= \frac{-2\cos x}{e^x}\end{aligned}\]

Setting \(\displaystyle f''(x)\) equal to zero to solve for possible inflection points gives:

\[\begin{aligned} 0 = \frac{-2\cos x}{e^x}\end{aligned}\]

or, equivalently,

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle \cos x = 0\end{aligned}\]

Using the unit circle we see that x = \(\pi\)/2 is the only solution in \([0,\pi]\) of the equation \(\cos(x) = 0\). This is our only possible point of inflection, because \(\displaystyle f''(x)\) is continuous everywhere. Testing the values of \(f''\left(\frac{\pi}2\right)\) with the second derivative test gives:

:{ class=“wikitable” - \([0,\pi/2)\) \(x = \pi/2\) \((\pi/2, \pi]\) - \(\displaystyle f''(x)\) - 0 + - \(\displaystyle f(x)\) concave down inflection point concave up }

Hence \(\displaystyle f(x)\) has an inflection point at \(x = \pi/2\).
